TopicTitle: Referencing squad textures for custom part

Articles.Content:
I know there's a dozen or more threads like this but after trying all the solutions I still can't get this to work,  I can and do combine models and textures all the time. 7 models 1 texture type of thing, but for some reason i can only get it to work within a folder or mod group of folders ie any folder within the main mod folder, but not in any other mod/Squad folder  , I've been trying to sort this for ages now and it's a little roadblock on the way to pushing the next Boomsticks update. 


 So what I have done is create an exact (ish) replica of the avionics nosecone and where on the stock model there's a dummy camera this model has a working image stabilized camera, and the antenna has been switched out for a cannon, makes a great combat drone. So it's all done and dusted and mapped to the same textures as the stock avionics nosecone, no problem, 'cept i can't distribute squad derived textures, so all I want to do is, like loads of you have done, use the model node and call the textures from the squad folder. 

	MODEL
	{
		model = BoomsticksRev3/Parts/CannonNoseCone/CannonNoseConeMK2
	
    texture = Cones, Squad/Parts/Aero/cones/Cones
	texture = Cones_Heat, Squad/Parts/Aero/cones/Cones_Heat
    texture = (local textures go here?)
   (

  Now I've checked the path a dozen times, chased my own tail, checked how others have done it etc etc  this is the path "E:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Kerbal Space Program\GameData\Squad\Parts\Aero\cones\Cones.dds" the texture is there i can see it, the path seems correct, I've created dummy textures for cones and cones heat as I've done elsewhere and yet all I get is texture not found and the subsequent failure to load the models. If i put my copies of the stock textures in the folder it will of course load absolutely trouble free.

This leads me to believe I'm missing something very obvious.  Still some areas i'm still rusty or unfamiliar with after my extended break and this is one of them. So gents any  help you'd like to direct this way would be most appreciated

So you are making dummy textures in the local folder, where the model is? That should work. Just to be clear, here are the steps I do that usually work, and what the pitfalls are that I've run into:

 

  • Export the model (mu) normally from Unity, with the texture being saved as MBM.
  • Don't let it export as PNG. Sometimes the "PNG" part of the filename is "sticky", and it won't want to remap to other texture types, for some buggy reason. This is inconsistent, but best avoided altogether.
  • Create a dummy texture to use in its place in the same folder as the new MU. It can often be a PNG, but I usually use MBM or DDS for this.
  • If the dummy texture is too small, say 4x4 or smaller, DDS format may result in it not loading properly. Use PNG or MBM if it is this small. I often make mine 16x16 if I want them to be DDS format. From an efficiency standpoint, the image format doesn't matter a whole lot, since the textures are so tiny.
  • If the dummy texture fails to load, then the "MODEL { texture = foo, path/to/bar }" reallocation will also fail.
  • Add the appropriate "texture = <old>, <path/to/new>" line to the CFG. The old name has to match both the texture filename that was stored for the material in the MU, and the filename of the dummy texture. The new path has to use forward-slashes (like in Linux), relative to GameData, and reference the actual texture file that will be used.

35 minutes ago, NecroBones said:

Don't let it export as PNG. Sometimes the "PNG" part of the filename is "sticky", and it won't want to remap to other texture types, for some buggy reason. This is inconsistent, but best avoided altogether.

Now this I did not know and sure enough it was exported as png.  Then again I've had issues with the dds conversions not being picked up as well, so this could be a likely culprit.

cheers
